Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Not much tbh
I developed a vast bank of knowledge surrounding many global food system problems that often go unseen or misunderstood by many consumers and producers of food products.
I learned fascinating new things every time I attended lecture
Understanding environmental regulation

Developed a much greater appreciation for the laws that govern US food and environment. Learned a ton about huge issues that are not so well known! It was a great class and should be taken by all yale students, no matter the major.
Tons!!!!! Great info
This course provides a unique interdisciplinary look at how environment, law, justice, intersect.

I learned new insights on the ways in which global food politics have developed throughout the past years along with the other environmental politics and laws that shape the ways in which we live and eat.
I learned a lot about the environment and how global environmental politics work.
I learned about many issues such as the hormonal impact of plastics, nuclear testing, and palm oil, which are so applicable in our lives and I knew nothing about before!

I learned about many challenges facing humans today, from plastics to pesticides to the food sector. This class made me aware of many new issues (such as food certification and palm oil) and furthered my knowledge and the pervasiveness of many other topics.
How the food industry works, the large corporations that control it and how the production and ingredients/pesticides use affect both consumers and the environment.
This course shined a light on many of the most important problems humans face today: food and the environment.

I learned a lot about the environmental impact of the foods/products I use on an everyday basis. I also learned about the history of food/tobacco/plastic legislation. Lastly, I gained knowledge about the global food system and the problems inherent in it.
I learned a lot about food regulation and the corruption of corporations to influence it.
I learned so much from taking this class. I think that I am able to look at food and the environment in a completely different way. I really appreciated this class, it was my favorite this semester.
Knowledge about the food industry, the various negative aspects of the institutions and legal frameworks surrounding food corporations
Lot's of information about the lack of stringency the US has with food laws, labeling, etc.
The issues plaguing the food system. How human health and diets need to change.

I developed a much greater insight into the nature of the global food system and some basic politics and laws controlling this system. It taught me the significance of the food system in terms of environmental damage and how much needs to change. It gave me a deeper knowledge of a specific research topic and how to address the problem and solution in essay format. Overall it really enlightened me about the (lack of) regulation controlling the food system and how this compares to drug and nuclear use.

This class was very interesting and had a lot of eye-opening information about global food systems. We did not talk a lot about specific policies, but we got a really great group overview of current issues relating to the environment and food.
So much! I loved the depth and breadth. I learned about so many topics I had little previous knowledge about.

I developed a broad knowledge into global food challenges and the possible national and international responses that could act as solutions to these challenges. I learnt how to be selective of the most important information when doing the readings for class.
Lectures were boring and not very engaging. Material is okay, readings are mostly scientific. It should be a relatively easy class though.

The information we learned throughout the course was tremendously and shockingly relevant to our everyday life. I have not yet had a class whose affect I could feel so consistently outside the classroom in terms of noticing aspects of the food systems around me I had not understood. On the other hand, the pacing of lecture slides often presented an obstacle to staying engaged in the course and I believe led to many people not attending all the lectures in the class.
I thought strengths were content chosen and delivery. I think weakness was the professor ran over time every single lecture.
Section was really fun and the topics were new to me
Its good

There is no other course like this at Yale, and I think the perspectives provided in the course teach you to think about the environment in a much deeper way. With that being said, this course is not suited for a lecture. The professor did not seem comfortable leading the lecture and tried covering way too much for the class to be engaging or enjoyable.
I think the course felt like it was bouncing around a lot and that there could have been a lot more depth on all topics

I think some of the readings could have been more engaged with the topics and the lecture powerpoint themselves might have been better structured with the information necessary for us to understand, learn, remember for the paper topics or exam.

Some weaknesses would definitely be that lectures were not always engaging and slides were often hard to follow. However, I think the course material is fascinating and if you really engage with it, you will get a lot out of section and the course.
The lectures were too long, and we never has enough time to finish the lecture in 50 mins. In addition, the paper assignments could have been much more straight forward.

I dont think the format of the final exam was goodi think having more shorter answers would be better.

I also think the order or topics was a little unintuitive.

This class was great. Professor Wargo is a very insightful professor with lots of knowledge to share. Lecture was only 50 min, twice a week so a lot of info was crammed into that time. Section was very useful, as students were pushed to consider many perspectives and different solutions to the problems we discussed. The papers (2000 to 2500 words) were also not overbearing. They were just long enough to require students to really look in depth into their chosen topics, but not long enough to pose a real burden on getting them done.
The lectures were not very well organized or easy to follow.
It seemed there was never enough time in lecture to cover everything that needed to be said. However, I believe those responsible for teaching did the best they could, it is a huge topic.
I don't think that the class had many weaknesses. It was set up well for learning.

Strengths - content is very interesting
weaknesses - could be more positive or show more positive solutions in the US and internationally
Sometimes disorganized. Lectures could get rambley. Didnt always tie together well. Lots of facts thrown at you.

The content in the course is truly fascinating and something I believe everyone should learn. It was at times very depressing and quite frightening but I think the overall message from the lectures and sections was very thought provoking and it made me reconsider many aspects of my life. I loved discussion section and always came away wanting to know more about the topic. I liked the range of subjects covered but think some sections could be covered in more depth. Great feedback from the TA.

I feel like the course didn't have much organisation. It presented itself as being about the environment, but for a straight month, none of the lecture topics touched on the environment, except for very superficial connections that felt more thrown in there to keep things semi relevant rather than actually thought out. It's also called "global" food challenges, but the focus of this course was not global at all. It was very US focused, with some splashes of the EU. And even within the US, it failed to address different socio-economic perspectives and experiences, it treated the entirety of the country as a single type of consumer. 
A strength I would say is that it really allows the student to explore topics they're interested in for the papers. This kind of also contributed to the class feeling disjointed, but I appreciated having that liberty.

One of the weaknesses of this course was that it was really broad. As an EVST major interested in food systems, I had already read about a lot of the things we talked about in class. As we go over so many topics, we don't go particularly in-depth on any of the topics, so sometimes it was frustrating because I felt like we did not go in depth enough.

Weakness - lecture could be dry, slides could be better organized, dry lectures occasionally
Strengths - the topics were SO INTERESTING and Wargo was so well-informed. Wow. I left every lecture with my mind blown and flummoxed by the idea of lunch. How could I eat after learning about endocrine-disrupting pesticide or plastic residue on my food?

I found that the lecture sometimes moved too fast and the overall semester format was quite confusing. The class engagement was not very high and this made it hard to be motivated in this class and in section.

I would recommend this class to any student interested in understanding the complexity of the food systems around us and their problems. Taking EVST 255 opened my eyes to many aspects of the world which I otherwise would have not paid any attention to. I will warn that if the class does not seem sufficiently interesting to you during shopping period then I would advise against taking the class.
Yes I think it broadens perspectives
I would recommend the course but beware that lectures can be boring sometimes.
This course should be required for all Yale College students! All of the information is incredibly valuable and will give you a new perspective on the world.
It's a great gut!
Yes
I would not recommend this to another student if the format is still a lecture.

If youve seen Food Inc or other similar documentaries about food + have thought about food and the environment much already, you probably know a lot of what this course has to offer. If youre a freshman and want to learn a bit about food/environment and practice writing in a low stress way, this could be a good course for you. I cant say that I got a lot out of it though, but its my fault for waiting until my last semester of college.
YES!! Very interesting topic that can relate to everyone as well as many topics and majors not considered similar.

I would definitely recommend this course. It has changed my thinking about our environment and the ways that I can change my own living habits to have less of a negative environmental impact. I also feel like I learned so much new material that I did not know, and it's really made me a more conscious consumer.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It was very interesting and Professor Wargo is a joy to listen to.
Yes! Really interesting and important topic.

Yes! I learned so much about things that are relevant to my everyday life. I got great feedback on my papers, both after submission and during the process of writing. I probably learned more about writing than I have in any other class (though I am only a first year). As a first year, I was challenged by the ability of upperclassmen to absorb so much information and speak concisely about it in section. This made me work hard to try to develop those speaking and information-gathering skills. As an EVST or PLSC credit, you won't find a more interesting class with information that is really relevant to your life.
I would. This is a very interesting topic worth learning of, regardless of your major.
Absolutely. It is so important, especially now that so many people do not understand how food is made and what resources the process takes.
Yes if they are interested in environmental politics
I would 100 percent recommend this course to another student. I really enjoyed the lectures and it was not hard to do well if you are willing to take the time and stay up to date with the readings.
Yes if you are interested in food and in the crossroads between environmental issues and the social sciences

Yes! The information learned in this class is necessary for everyone to have, in order to make positive environmental change in years to come. It is beneficial for understanding climate change, as well as how these modern-day climate issues are intersectional with race and class. I would recommend this course to anyone and everyone with even the slightest interest in these topics, as they are topics in which everyone should have a basic level understanding.
Yes if you need EVST humanities it's one of the better choices
Yes, the content is something I believe everyone should learn and very interesting. It will change the way you look at the wold. The structure and workload of the course is also very manageable.
ABSOLUTELY. It will blow your mind, keep you engaged, and change your relationship with food and your environment.

Yes to fill a course requirement but, I did not enjoy it as much as I expected. It was horrifying learning about the global challenges with little focus on what solutions could be and which are achievable.
yes! Wargo is very knowledgable and great!
